title: Trump team impeachment strategy? Make it a slog
text:
The fight is a risky one for Democrats, who are well aware that getting caught in a protracted courtroom slog could cost them a chance to pounce while the president is on the defensive, facing sagging poll numbers and near-peak public focus on a budding scandal over his efforts to pressure Ukrainian officials to investigate his political rival, Joe Biden.

“There’s no reason in this case Congress has to go down that path at all,” said Phil Barnett, who served for more than a decade as a top aide to Democratic oversight heavyweight Rep. Henry Waxman and is currently informally advising party leadership on its efforts. “They know the key facts already, so this is like trying to close the barn door after the horse has already left.”

poster="https://static.politico.com/76/1d/89d23a804d4d95f3083b6e9593d4/trumpimpeachment.jpg"

Democrats recognize that the approach might lead them into yet another quagmire. Trump’s team has already successfully slow walked the release of dishy details at the center of Robert Mueller’s Russia probe, as well as the president’s tax returns, turning once hot-button issues into protracted, arcane legal fights.

“We're not fooling around here,” House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff, the California Democrat who has become Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s new point man on impeachment, told reporters Wednesday at the Capitol. “We don’t want this to drag on months and months and months, which appears to be the administration's strategy.”

Still, for now, Democrats are choosing to pursue more evidence instead of just moving forward with the already-available facts. And if they do get bogged down, the backup plan is to simply add the Trump allies’ legal tactics to the articles of impeachment.

“They will be strengthening the case on obstruction if they behave that way,” Schiff said.

The approach has opened up several potential battlefronts in the fight to uncover more information about a July phone call Trump had with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

During that call, Trump repeatedly asked Zelensky to look into Biden’s role as vice president during the Obama administration in pushing for the ouster of the top Ukrainian investigator. Trump’s allies have claimed that Biden made the move to quash an investigation into work that his son, Hunter Biden, did with a Ukrainian gas company, although no evidence has emerged of any wrongdoing. Trump also asked Zelensky for an investigation into unfounded allegations that Ukrainian officials attempted to help Hillary Clinton during the 2016 election.

The House Oversight Committee has said it will subpoena the White House on Friday for documents connected to the incident.

The Democrats are also trying to obtain documents from Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s personal lawyer who has spent months trying to convince Ukraine to launch investigations into Biden and his son. The pugnacious former New York mayor himself lawyered up after getting a subpoena Monday from three House committees demanding materials about his communications with Ukrainian officials.

A similar fight is taking place over Democratic attempts to subpoena materials from the State Department and specifically from Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who on Wednesday confirmed he was on the Trump-Zelensky call. Lawmakers also have been trying to arrange sit-down depositions with five current and former State employees. The first one of these interviews is set for Thursday, when Kurt Volker, the recently departed special envoy for Ukraine, will meet with congressional aides.

In each instance, Trump officials and allies have responded with legal arguments aimed at preemptively blocking the overtures.

In an interview Wednesday night, Giuliani said that “in order to obey” the subpoenas, “I’d have to violate attorney-client privilege.” Therefore, he added, disputing the subpoenas “would be taking the high road.”

Giuliani on Tuesday also suggested he plans to sue Congress and “the swamp” in retribution for the impeachment inquiry — a tactic Trump lawyers have also used at the federal and state level to halt the release of his tax returns. Wednesday night, Giuliani added that if Democrats hold him in contempt for refusing to comply with the subpoenas, “they would just be making my lawsuit better.”

Pompeo in a letter on Tuesday argued that the demands conflicted with the department’s “interest in safeguarding potentially privileged and classified information.” He also slammed Democrats for having “no legal basis for such a threat” about obstruction.

“I urge you to exercise restraint in making such unfounded statements in the future,” he said.

For their part, the White House called the subpoenas a “kangaroo court” effort.

“This is nothing but more document requests, wasted time and taxpayer dollars that will ultimately show the President did nothing wrong,” said White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham.

In his own hyperbolic manner, Trump himself has vaguely alleged that the Democrats’ attempts to publicize the incident and gather information about it is illegal, claiming that Schiff should be prosecuted for treason over his description of Trump’s phone call with Zelensky.

While the president’s lawyers haven’t used such colorful language, they too are signaling they have shifted into war footing and hope to draw Democrats into court.

“There are significant constitutional issues raised by the subpoenas,” said Jay Sekulow, one of the lead members of the president’s personal legal team in a text message. He added that the subpoena demands will be “responded to appropriately” and struck back at the Democratic allegations that a refusal to comply constitutes obstruction.

“Arguing that following constitutional mandates is obstruction is absurd. Read Article 2,” Sekulow said.

Legal experts say these tactics shouldn’t rattle Democrats. They argue that Pelosi likely holds the winning hand in court if she wants to try and challenge the Trump team’s specific defenses.

Giuliani, for example, may have undercut his own claims in public, according to several legal analysts. He’s claimed that he works for Trump in other capacities, beyond just being his lawyer, which could undercut his attorney-client privilege argument. And it’s unlikely that all of his outreach to Ukrainian officials is legally protected. Then there are Giuliani’s ubiquitous media appearances.

“He’s yakking all the time. Assuming he’s been doing his yakking with the permission of the president, that’s very likely constitutes a waiver to some , if not all of it,” said Frank Bowman, a University of Missouri law professor.

But Bowman, the author of the new book “High Crimes and Misdemeanors,” said Democrats who are intent on capturing all of the current focus on impeachment may not want to go down the litigation path — even if they know they’d win.

“The trouble is if you want to get information out of Giuliani you’re going to have to get it one axe fight at a time,” he said. “It’s unlikely to be a blanket rule on him. As an investigator, you’ve got to work fact by fact, communication by communication, observation by observation and fight it out that way, which is obviously a long and tedious process.”

That’s the message that Pelosi and her deputies are hearing from Democratic veterans and advisers like Barnett, the former Waxman aide. Barnett is informally advising Democratic leaders on the subject with his longtime partner, Phil Schiliro, a former Obama White House legislative director.

Calling out Pompeo specifically, Barnett said the secretary of State has no legal ability to block his employees from giving testimony to lawmakers. He cited a 1912 law — the Lloyd-La Follette Act — that gives civil servants the ability to furnish information to Congress, as well as any U.S. citizen’s fundamental First Amendment protections. “Not only is it obstructing the investigation, it’s directly contrary to federal law on something that he’s personally implicated in,” he said.

Another area where Democrats will be battling Trump is over access to classified materials.

While the White House last week surprised many lawmakers by clearing the release of a summary transcript of the president’s call with Zelensky, they may not be so forthcoming in the future. Pompeo’s letter on Tuesday cited classified information as one reason he could not fulfill Democrats’ demands.

Legal experts said Democrats may need to find workarounds to avoid doing battle with the administration’s law enforcement and intelligence arms over the topic.

“The House could deliver articles of impeachment to the Senate having had some evidence presented in a classified setting, and classifying some of the final report as a result,” said Greg Brower, who served as the FBI’s top liaison to Congress until 2018.

But once the impeachment process moves to the Senate — where Trump would essentially be defending himself in a courtroom setting with 100 jurors and both sides allowed to present their cases publicly — keeping some information private becomes more difficult.

“You’d have an open trial in which some of the evidence is classified,” Brower said. “I could see the administration crying afoul and accusing lawmakers of doing some kind of secret proceeding.”

Still, Mieke Eoyang, the Vice President for Third Way's National Security Program and a former staff director on the House Intelligence Committee, noted that Congress isn’t legally bound by the president’s classification scheme and can technically put almost anything into the legislative record.

The executive branch “cannot bind the legislative branch,” Eoyang said. “Congress only respects it as a matter of courtesy and principle.”

Natasha Bertrand and Matthew Choi contributed to this report.
